bug.author: frankstack
bug.summary: ray.init() error - "Retrying to connect to socket for pathname tcp..."
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h3>What is the problem?</denchmark-h>
Unable to ray.init() on Spyder 4.0 for Windows. <denchmark-h:h3>Explanation</denchmark-h>
I've just try to initialize ray in my Spyder by import ray and later defining: ray.init() However, my Sypder 4.0 gives me back this error in the console:
runfile('C:/Users/FRANK/Anaconda3/envs/testenv/test_ray.py', wdir='C:/Users/FRANK/Anaconda3/envs/testenv') 2020-09-08 16:35:42,212 INFO resource_spec.py:212 -- Starting Ray with 10.11 GiB memory available for workers and up to 5.07 GiB for objects. You can adjust these settings with ray.init(memory=, object_store_memory=). 2020-09-08 16:35:42,791 INFO services.py:1165 -- View the Ray dashboard at localhost:8265 E0908 16:35:48.064086 16612 25632 raylet_client.cc:69] Retrying to connect to socket for pathname tcp://127.0.0.1:58478 (num_attempts = 1, num_retries = 10) E0908 16:35:48.064086 16612 25632 raylet_client.cc:69] Retrying to connect to It seems extremely strange for me because I tried ray in a Jupyter Notebook of the same environment (testenv) before, and it works without any problems. It works even doing ray.init() or ray.init(include_webui=False). Nevertheless, there is a slightly difference between them. For the ray.init() simple case in my Jupyter Notebook, it returns:
2020-09-08 16:53:14,543 INFO resource_spec.py:212 -- Starting Ray with 9.96 GiB memory available for workers and up to 5.0 GiB for objects. You can adjust these settings with ray.init(memory=, object_store_memory=). 2020-09-08 16:53:15,558 INFO services.py:1165 -- View the Ray dashboard at localhost:8265 {'node_ip_address': '192.168.0.3', 'raylet_ip_address': '192.168.0.3', 'redis_address': '192.168.0.3:6379', 'object_store_address': 'tcp://127.0.0.1:63559', 'raylet_socket_name': 'tcp://127.0.0.1:60862', 'webui_url': 'localhost:8265', 'session_dir': 'C:\Users\FRANK\AppData\Local\Temp\ray\session_2020-09-08_16-53-14_531203_10492'} 2020-09-08 16:53:18,457 WARNING worker.py:1047 -- The dashboard on node DESKTOP-N8JUB39 failed with the following error: Traceback (most recent call last): File "C:\Users\FRANK\Anaconda3\envs\testenv\lib\site-packages\ray\dashboard/dashboard.py", line 960, in metrics_export_address=metrics_export_address) File "C:\Users\FRANK\Anaconda3\envs\testenv\lib\site-packages\ray\dashboard/dashboard.py", line 513, in init build_dir = setup_static_dir(self.app) File "C:\Users\FRANK\Anaconda3\envs\testenv\lib\site-packages\ray\dashboard/dashboard.py", line 414, in setup_static_dir "&& npm run build)", build_dir) FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] Dashboard build directory not found. If installing from source, please follow the additional steps required to build the dashboard(cd python/ray/dashboard/client && npm ci && npm run build): 'C:\Users\FRANK\Anaconda3\envs\testenv\lib\site-packages\ray\dashboard\client/build'
For the ray.init(include_webui=False) case, the cell give me back just:
2020-09-08 14:53:09,994 INFO resource_spec.py:212 -- Starting Ray with 10.5 GiB memory available for workers and up to 5.26 GiB for objects. You can adjust these settings with ray.init(memory=, object_store_memory=). {'node_ip_address': '192.168.0.3', 'raylet_ip_address': '192.168.0.3', 'redis_address': '192.168.0.3:6379', 'object_store_address': 'tcp://127.0.0.1:60655', 'raylet_socket_name': 'tcp://127.0.0.1:65214', 'webui_url': None, 'session_dir': 'C:\Users\FRANK\AppData\Local\Temp\ray\session_2020-09-08_14-53-09_990619_17552'}
Perhaps the ray.init() Warning Message in the Jupyter Notebook is related with the problem in Spyder. I'm not sure. Just to add. I've figure out that this problem was the pretty much the same that in a previous closed issue <denchmark-link:https://github.com/ray-project/ray/issues/9410>#9410</denchmark-link> . But the answers were too lazyâ€”basically, the conclusion was that the antivirus cause this problem. I tried disabling my Avast Free antivirus and including Anaconda and everything related with python into their exceptions, but nothing seems to work. Moreover, in this case, my kernel is trying to fits the requirement of by trying to initialize it. Maybe that's why my kernel is restarting until the message arrives. Here I leave my python -c "import sys; print(sys.version)" result in the cmd for this environment:
(testenv) C:\Users\FRANK>python -c "import sys; print(sys.version)" 3.6.10 |Anaconda, Inc.| (default, May 7 2020, 19:46:08) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)]

I find ray very useful. However, I would like your help in solving this issue. Many thanks. If we cannot run your script, we cannot fix your issue.
I have verified my script runs in a clean environment and reproduces the issue. I have verified the issue also occurs with the latest wheels.

comments.comment: Hmm yeah <denchmark-link:https://github.com/frankstack>@frankstack</denchmark-link> thanks a bunch for opening this issue. I wish we had a better diagnostic tool for this. cc <denchmark-link:https://github.com/mehrdadn>@mehrdadn</denchmark-link> do you have any thoughts?

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/richardliaw>@richardliaw</denchmark-link> Not anything beyond my comment on the other issue currently. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/frankstack>@frankstack</denchmark-link> For what it's worth, it may still be your antivirus, as some antiviruses still keep their drivers loaded and don't entirely turn off despite what the GUI may tell you. It would be nice if you can reproduce this on a system that's never had any AV installed at all. However, if that doesn't seem to be the issue, what is your response regarding <denchmark-link:/ray-project/ray/issues/9410#issuecomment-656936821>the other steps in my comment</denchmark-link> (in particular the Process Explorer part)? Oh, also, it'd be nice to check if Python >= 3.8.2 behave similarly.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/mehrdadn>@mehrdadn</denchmark-link> Oh no, sorry. There is nothing wrong with your previous answer. It's just that I thought maybe I could find more information. But don't worry. I just tried using a new environment with python 3.8.2 as you told me, and it works without any problem. Many thanks! Many thanks for your support!
